Award.AwardTitle: CDI-Type II: Collaborative Research: A Paradigm Shift in Ecosystem and Environmental Modeling: An Integrated Stochastic, Deterministic, and Machine Learning Approach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will advance systems modeling approaches by developing a suite of stochastic modeling approaches, coupled with geostatistical and machine learning techniques. The new system modeling approach will utilize both in situ and satellite remotely sensed data to improve system model parameters and model structure. These novel developments, together with observed data, will advance ecosystem and environmental sciences through computational thinking. The proposed approach will be used to develop a cyber-enabled stochastic carbon-weather system to provide more adequate quantification of regional carbon exchanges, which is critical to better understanding carbon-climate-atmosphere feedbacks and facilitating climate-policy making.


The proposed approach will transform the current system modeling approach by (1) developing a stochastic version of the deterministic differential equation models of ecosystems and environmental systems; (2) developing geospatial statistical techniques to fully exploit multifaceted observational data to improve model parameterization; (3) developing advanced statistical and machine learning techniques to further utilize observational data to improve model structure; and (4) applying the improved model to examine the societal and biogeochemical impacts of land use change. Advantages of the proposed cyber-enabled terrestrial ecosystem model will include: (1) Efficiently quantifying regional net carbon exchanges and associated uncertainty and (2) Improving system model parameters and structure using advanced statistical and machine learning techniques and spatiotemporal data acquired over the U.S. Project deliverables include: (1) An innovative, cyber-enabled carbon-weather system that can quantify net carbon exchanges and associated probabilistic information at high spatial and temporal resolution for the continental U.S. and (2) a suite of transformative advanced mathematical, statistical and system modeling techniques that could be applied to other complex modeling fields (e.g., hydrological modeling). This project will significantly advance ecosystem sciences with computational thinking and will provide a unique opportunity to train a new generation of scientists in a highly interdisciplinary research environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Environmental sciences are in big-data era.  To take advantage of multivariate data across space and time to advance environmental sciences, this project developed a series of model-data fusion tools based on statistical, mathematical, and computational theories and techniques. Our technical development is focused on the following areas: 1) techniques to address scaling issues in modeling ecosystem carbon dynamics; 2) spatially-explicit parameterization methods for ecosystem modeling; 3) adjoint approaches for effectively using observation data to advance ecosystem sciences and modeling; 4) statistical Bayesian approaches to improve system model parameterization and to conduct uncertainty analysis due to uncertain models and their parameters; and 5) fast spin-up methods for improving system modeling. 

With the developed mathematical, statistical, and computational tools, this project has advanced ecosystem and environmental sciences significantly.  These sciences have high impacts on our managing and utilizing natural resources as well as ecosystems goods and services.  The findings will facilitate climate policy-making and socioeconomic decision-making including land use and bioenergy use. Specifically, our research enhanced the science in the following fields: 1) soil decomposition modeling by considering soil thermal effects and more detailed microbial decomposition processes; 2) the plant carbon uptake knowledge by considering the effects of aerosols on photosynthesis, ecosystem acclimation to changing climate, the effects of organic nitrogen uptake by plants on the carbon cycling; 3) the impacts of extreme events (e.g., drought and heat wave) on plant productivity and carbon cycling; and 4) crop yield modeling to study biofuel implementation and its consequences to our environment.

            Research findings of this project can guide socioeconomic development in several ways.  First, our research on improving quantification on carbon sequestration of both natural and managed ecosystems will help make climate and carbon emission policy at national and international levels. Second, our findings on crop yield under extreme events will help farming under a changing climate.  Third, our bioenergy modeling studies provide the public quantitative information on the feasibility of growing bioenergy crops while having a food security given that the arable land is limited.

            This project developed a web-based research and educational ecosystem modeling tool, which is based on Purdue high performance computing system to allow users to estimate plant productivity and carbon sequestration of terrestrial ecosystems. This project also trained a new generation of scientists who are equipped with advanced knowledge of ecosystem and environmental sciences and skills of mathematical, statistical, and computation skills.
